My name is Richard and I'm the lead

and I are responsible for all of the
scan post-processing tools that um

uh asset types as they're introduced

But before we get into that and for
anyone who's maybe new or doesn't have
much experience with Mega Scans, uh you
know what is it and how can you get the
most out of it in your own projects?
Well, Mega Scans is a comprehensive
library of photorealistic assets created
by scanning real world objects and
surfaces from all over the world. Our
extensive collection covers dozens of
unique biomes and includes detailed
vegetation, natural surfaces, as well as
man-made structures, props, and so much
more. This makes them particularly
valuable in areas like games, VFX,
automotive, and architectural
visualization, significantly cutting
down the time and effort required to
create lifelike uh environments from
scratch.
Being integrated into the Epic ecosystem
means that we're committed to providing
premium scalable content that benefits
all creators from large studios to
independent creators. Our assets empower
teams of every size to streamline their
workflow, enabling everyone to reach
their creative goals effectively and
efficiently.
So, we have a diverse collection of
assets from all over the world, but we
also have a diverse collection of asset
types, which are all designed to be used
together in your scene. Our 3D assets
form the backbone of detailed world
building, and they offer a wide range of
props and elements to fill your
environments.
This lets you stay in your creative
flow, focusing less on asset creation
and more on creativity. Our modular
assets act like building blocks designed
for grid snapping
um as well as use in parametric tools.
And then we have specialized vegetation
assets. These are built from individual
scan elements and then handcrafted into
realistic lush plants with age and
health variants to name just a few of
the parameters.
And then we have full 3D trees which are
some of the most complex assets in our

constructed entirely from real world
scan data and then combined with
powerful procedural systems which
perfectly complement our smaller
vegetation assets. Things like wind,
seasonality, and health can all be
controlled from a single blueprint
actor, allowing you to tame the natural

Our surface assets are highly detailed
scan texture sets ideal for any
surfaces, terrains, and even props that

our scanning process begins long before

within the library. To capture the
highest quality data, we use a
customuilt hardware rig with the DSLR

as well as a backpack containing um a
large battery pack so that the scan team
can be out in the field for hours at a
time. We refer to this setup as the
flash scanner and I'll refer back to it

mostly consists of Sony A7R3 cameras
which has been our work for our
workhorse for the last few years which
shoots roughly 42 megapixel images. Um,
the number of images per scan varies
dramatically on the the type of scan
we're doing, but it could be anywhere
from a couple hundred to several
thousand images.
The flashes on the rig allow us to
cancel out any ambient lighting and
shadows that may be present at the time.
And the polarizing filters are placed
both on the flashes and the camera
orientated at 90° offset. Uh this
arrangement produces cross polarized
images that capture only the base color
removing any specular reflections and
other reflectance components.
Um throughout the entire scanning
workflow, we follow rigorous best
practices to make sure that we get even
coverage as any issues with the scan uh
will show up later in the process and
it's generally uh takes way longer to
fix down the line than on site.
On the calibration side, we ensure that
all scans include a McBth color chart
and a custom scale marker. This gives us
critical data when calibrating our scans
later on. The color checker ensures
accurate color calibration and reliable
white balancing resulting in
true-to-life color representation
without introducing subjective biases.
There could be subtle uh ambient
lighting on the day that is almost
enough to overpower the light the
flashes or you know um uh settings on
the camera which maybe change the the
calibration. So having that data is is
really important for us. And then the
inclusion of scale markers allows us to
capture precise dimensions resulting in
a onetoone version of the asset with no
guesswork about the scale of the asset
afterwards.
In the top image, you can also see a red
laser guide. Um this is actually from
two lasers which are attached to the rig
which converge and uh align with each

scanners, we need to account for the
fall off of light. So the follow of life
light over distance when scanning. So
the scan artist knows that as soon as
those two markers line up with each
other that's the right distance away. So
that's a calibrated distance.
During scanning we use a proprietary

essential reference imagery detailed

All of which streamlines the asset

Uh this is critical when dealing with

After scanning the asset data is

Each processing stage generates new data

The centralized application is used for

In this next section, we'll take a look

photoggramometry results and the mega

the best balance between quality and

Instead of working with extremely high

300 million triangles.
This mesh density provides ample
geometric detail, allowing us to
confidently generate highdetail assets

export a secondary mesh at 50 million

uh for hosting a 32K base color map,

And finally, we'll look at cases where

So, one of the most important
considerations is the legal review
process. IP compliance is critical for
ensuring that our scanned content is
safe to use in commercial projects like
games, films, and any content that gets
sold on FAB. Common IP issues include
barcodes, labels, brand names,
distinctive or identifiable designs, and
unique aesthetics on handmade items.
In cases like this picture frame and
artwork, we would remove the artwork
itself, leaving just the picture frame.
Um, which arguably gives a more
versatile and modular asset that can be
used in different situations.
To further support awareness and
compliance, we've published detailed
documentation on EDC on this topic that
outlines best practices and explains the
legal review process for scanbased
content.
Then we get to additive construction
reconstruction. So sometimes capturing a
complete scan just isn't feasible either
because parts of the scan aren't
accessible or the form isn't ideal from
all angles. In these cases, we use
additive reconstruction, completing
partial scans by carefully modeling,
sculpting and additional details,
merging scan data to form complete
structures, always relying on scan data
to fill the gaps.
This additive approach helps us create
complete and versatile assets. It
ensures assets remain usable from
various angles, expanding possibilities
of creative world building and flexible
scene assembling. By avoiding exposed
mesh boundaries, you don't need extra
geometry to hide gaps in your scenes and
your meshes, potentially keeping your
project within budget. It also means
that you don't have to limit player
movement or restrict their view,
preserving player agency.
Then we get to texture reprocessing. So
in some cases where it is impractical to
scan with the flash scanner that I
mentioned earlier, such as drone scans
or large canyons or in this case a few
stories up on a residential building. Um
for large scans, it's impractical to to
use the flash scanner just because of
the falloff of light and we just end up
not getting any real benefit from the
the flashes.
So in these cases, we post-process the
base color map to reduce any baked
shadows as we need to have a perfectly
flat starting point to be able to
relight in UEIE without being biased by
the the lighting conditions on the day
of scanning.
As we scan with a cross polarized setup
which cuts out any reflectance values,
we also need to enhance these assets by

including refined maps for specular
roughness, gloss, base color, and

So here you can see a difference between

process.
One of the things that makes scanned

A lot of our architectural scans um have

To better support diverse use cases,
we've introduced a new asset tier system
which is now available on Fab. Instead
of traditional LODs, assets are
organized into quality tiers. The
highest quality tier is designed
specifically for use cases such as in
camera VFX and nanite workflows. Ideal
for projects demanding m maximum visual
fidelity, while the lower quality tiers
are tailored for platforms with resource
or bandwidth constraints, mobile
hardware, or projects where storage

In this example, you can see a

and its UEFN counterpart. There is this
is no longer just an LOD, but rather a

One of the key goals with the new tier
system was consistency and asset
complexity and detail. Assets of similar
size and complexity now maintain roughly
the same triangle count across each
quality tier. As illustrated here,
the standardization helps to simplify
optimization, ensuring that you get more
predictable performance and visual
quality when placing assets from the

Previously, a high quality meshes
received a lot of attention in mesh and

even when viewed closely or used

As mentioned earlier, we also have
higher material accuracy for our

Um, a spectrometer is a device that

providing precise real world data to
ensure accurate reference values.
This provides artists with a lookup
table as a reliable guidance when
creating PBR maps for assets.
And when it comes to displacement, uh,
one of the biggest pain points when
using displacement is the need to refine
and tweak scale and bias values in your
shaders. If you have ever needed to
tweak displacement shaders in your
scene, you'll know exactly what I mean.
We wanted to mitigate this by
pre-calibrating our entire library
across 3D surfaces and atlases to avoid
having to spend any time worrying about
this problem ever again.
This calibration process gives us
precise values that represent real world
distance that a displacement map
represents.
This then allows us to plug these values
directly into the magnitude and center
values in the shader and gives precise
displacement values without any further
manipulation.
This removes any shader logic which can
be daunting to new users. And setting
the magnitude and center is at least at
the moment the most optimized way to
work with displacement in UEIE.
We provide two standards for our
displacement maps. We have a 32bit
floating point EXR with real world
distances baked into the pixel values.
These are zero biased maps designed to
be used with no additional offsets.
We also have an 8-bit JPEG which is
normalized 0 to255 which then makes use
of the scale and bias values stored in
the metadata to achieve the same
mathematical range as the EXR but with a
fraction of the cost.
Here we have this working on a surface

For surface assets, it's important to

These dimensions can be found in the

So first up we have a heat map

and quantifiable measure of scan

to scanning teams where additional
capture may be required. It also guides

It can enable early detection of

And looking ahead, we plan to utilize

As you may know, generating highquality
UVs for assets can take a considerable
amount of time. So because of this,
we've developed our own UV generation
tool to auto unwrap complex assets.
With this approach, we start at the
individual triangle level, assigning
each triangle to a patch of its own and
work iteratively outward, gathering
neighbor neighbor uh neighboring
triangles that satisfy some criteria
into larger and larger patches.
At each step, we query the
characteristics of neighboring patches
to determine which, if any, to join up
with. By recalculating those
characteristics when the patches merge,
we can dynamically adjust our goals for
the next round of merges towards reduced
distortion when the resultant patches
are eventually flattened from 3D into UV
space.
This UV layout can then be used either
as a starting point for an artist to
finalize or as the final UV layout for
simpler models.
Texture baking, for anyone that doesn't
know, is the process of transferring
mesh or texture information from a
source mesh to a target. This typically
involves the use of casting rays,
collecting results, and writing an
image. But occasionally, these rays are
unable to return the right data, and
when this happens, you end up with bake
artifacts in the image. Typical baking
processes involve the use of a cage,
which dictates the direction and max
distance that array can travel. This
works well in very controlled
environments or when an artist is able
to author the cage. But we found that
with the unpredictable nature of
photoggramometry topology and the need
for full automation, a simple cage
approach was unable to fully envelop the
meshes in many cases.
Even with an uh iterative solverbased
approach for finding the best coverage,
there's still numerous cases of
undercoage leading to holes in the baked
baked texture or over coverage which
reintroduce the over projection
artifacts which we were trying to solve
in the first place. So our solution to
all of this um avoids all of the cage
related limitations of skewing bake
normals being tied to mesh topology etc.
And that was to develop what we call
blocker meshes. So this uh two-sided
geometry effectively is shown in blue in
this diagram wraps around both the red
source and the green target mesh like a
sock and prevents pretty much all of the
projection artifacts as the bake rays
only have a single valid target for them
to reach.
If array fires in one direction and hits
the blocker, then they simply retry and
cast in the other direction, returning
the correct result.
After implementing this into our
workflows, we've seen a dramatic
decrease in the number and severity of
texture bake related artifacts during
processing, resulting in way less artist
time, if any, needed to clean these up.
So, in order to create clean UVs and
game ready topology, our workflow is
designed initially to operate on much
lower resolution meshes. Once this mesh
is approved, it is run through an
iterative subdivision and reprojection
process to reintroduce all of the
highfidelity meshes from the scan, which
gives us perfectly optimized UVs on
multi-million uh triangle meshes.
So the project tool runs a progressive
subdivide and projection operation. The
tool is able to take a low poly mesh and
iteratively subdivide and project
against a much higher target mesh. So in
these illustrations, you can see it
looks like a um poly reduction in
reverse, but it's actually us projecting
back all of the high quality details
onto that base mesh.
Very importantly, the iterative step
includes error checking passes so that
each round of projection can start on a
very clean mesh. Therefore, bad
projections don't compound over time. in
naive solutions to this. A single bad
projection on an early iteration can
lead to a complete rat's nest of uh
geometry that's very very difficult to
resolve after projecting over and over.
So array logic avoids all of these types
of issues.
And then in order for us to hit the

So this process optimizes the triangle

against specific criteria.
Initially the input mesh is cleaned and

reduction.
Candidates are then scored at different

for adaptive triangle retention, meaning
a mesh with high complexity can retain
more input triangles.
